title: 109_hr3109
content: The Act titled "Cybersecurity Education Enhancement Act of 2005" establishes cybersecurity training programs and equipment within the Department of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the National Science Foundation, will award grants to higher education institutions for cybersecurity professional development and associate degree programs, as well as equipment purchase. The Secretary will set program goals in consultation with the National Science Foundation Director. The program established under this section will be operated by the National Science Foundation, with the Secretary transferring necessary funds. Awards will be provided based on competitive, merit-reviewed criteria, with a focus on geographic diversity. The Director aims to ensure geographic diversity and the participation of women and minorities in awarding grants. Preference is given to consortium applications to benefit more students and professionals, especially those from institutions eligible for funds under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary is authorized to receive $3,700,000 for each of fiscal years 2006 and 2007 for this section. SEC. 226. E-Security Fellows Program established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Secretary shall establish a fellowship program for State, local, tribal, and private sector officials to participate in the National Cybersecurity Division's work, focusing on enhancing government cybersecurity, developing partnerships, and improving information sharing on cyber threats. The E-Security Fellows Program aims to enhance government cybersecurity by providing incident response planning, fostering training, and certification. Eligibility requires cybersecurity responsibilities and national security clearance. The program consists of two 180-day iterations per year to ensure Division activities are not impeded. The E-Security Fellows Program requires employers to continue paying fellows' salaries and benefits during the fellowship. Fellows receive a stipend to cover living expenses. The E-Security Fellows Program requires employers to pay fellows' salaries and benefits while providing a stipend for living expenses.
